Issues.Title: CollectionViewSource live filtering can hide item(s) when adding items and quickly changing their filter status afterwards.
Issues.Body:
### Description

A user of our software noticed that sometimes when opening a page in our WPF application that an item was missing from a `DataGrid`.
Since this DataGrid needs to be sorted and show either all items, or items that require attention based on a toggle, we used a `CollectionViewSource` like so:
```
<CollectionViewSource
    x:Key="ItemsFilterAndSorter"
    Filter="FilteringEvent"
    IsLiveFilteringRequested="True"
    Source="{Binding Items}">
    <CollectionViewSource.SortDescriptions>
        <componentModel:SortDescription PropertyName="Name" />
    </CollectionViewSource.SortDescriptions>
    <CollectionViewSource.LiveFilteringProperties>
        <system:String>IsVisibleThroughFilter</system:String>
    </CollectionViewSource.LiveFilteringProperties>
</CollectionViewSource>
``` 

The Filter is an event that is defined like so:
```c#
private void FilteringEvent(object sender, FilterEventArgs e)
{
    e.Accepted = (e.Item as IFilterable)?.IsVisibleThroughFilter == true;
}
``` 

Then upon opening the page, the application waits for an network reply asynchronously and fills an `ObservableCollection<T>` from a secondary thread. For that we do use the `BindingOperations.EnableCollectionSynchronization(Items, sync)` system to let WPF know it's asynchronous.

Then our items add/update function can be boiled down to this:
```c#
for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++)
{
    lock(sync)
    {
        Items.Add(new Item(i));
    }
}

foreach (var item in Items)
{
    item.IsVisibleThroughFilter = true;
}
``` 

By default the `IsVisibleThroughFilter` is false, and is set to true after adding.
What I expect, is that the binding to `IsVisibleThroughFilter` happens after the initial check that is done in the `FilteringEvent`. And because of that there's a small gap in time that allows an Item to be added that is not visible at start, then marked as visible and then subscribed to changes of the `IsVisibleThroughFilter` property, making the `CollectionViewSource` not update the actual view.

So, I'm not sure I'm using `CollectionViewSource` as intended, but the documentation also doesn't seem to forbid what I'm doing.

### Reproduction Steps

Using the code from the description you can build a reproduction, but it takes time as the time gap at which this can happen seems to be quite small. Our product can run quite heavily so the `Dispatcher` is more occupied than with the code samples I've given.

### Expected behavior

I expect the `CollectionViewSource` to subscribe to the property before taking the initial value of the filter, ensuring all items are displayed as requested.

### Actual behavior

There's a small chance that item(s) are not displayed, until the `IsVisibleThroughFilter` property is changed.

### Regression?

I'm not sure, for now our product is stuck on .NET 4.7.1

### Known Workarounds

- Set the `IsVisibleThroughFilter` property correctly before adding to the `ObservableCollection<T>`.
In our case this works fine because other updates take a while, but milage may vary. If the user quickly toggles the filter manually theoretically it could also occur.

- Change the `IsVisibleThroughFilter` property

### Impact

The users of our software can't fully know if data in the list is displayed accurately.

### Configuration

- .NET 4.7.1
- Windows 11 Pro - Version 22H2 (OS Build 22621.3880)
- x64
- AFAIK not specific to my configuration

### Other information

_No response_

Issues.Title: System.OverflowException in WriteableBitmap.WritePixels
Issues.Body:
### Description

`WriteableBitmap` can not exceed 4 GB I think (`WriteableBitmap` constructor fails) but even for sizes below 4 GB (but above 2GB) there are overflow exceptions in `WriteableBitmap.WritePixels`, even when only writing a tiny amount of data.


### Reproduction Steps

```
                int size = 30000;
                int tileSize = 100;
                int channels = 4;
                var pix = new byte[tileSize * tileSize * channels];
                var bitmap = new WriteableBitmap(size, size, 96, 96, PixelFormats.Pbgra32, null);
                bitmap.WritePixels(new Int32Rect(0, 0, tileSize, tileSize),
                      pix, tileSize * channels, size-tileSize, size-tileSize);
```

### Expected behavior

No exception. (Or if >2GB is considered unsupported, the constructor should already fail?)

### Actual behavior

Exception:
```
System.OverflowException
  HResult=0x80131516
  Message=Arithmetic operation resulted in an overflow.
  Source=PresentationCore
  StackTrace:
   at System.Windows.Media.Imaging.WriteableBitmap.WritePixelsImpl(Int32Rect sourceRect, IntPtr sourceBuffer, Int32 sourceBufferSize, Int32 sourceBufferStride, Int32 destinationX, Int32 destinationY, Boolean backwardsCompat) in System.Windows.Media.Imaging\WriteableBitmap.cs:line 583
   at System.Windows.Media.Imaging.WriteableBitmap.WritePixels(Int32Rect sourceRect, Array sourceBuffer, Int32 sourceBufferStride, Int32 destinationX, Int32 destinationY) in System.Windows.Media.Imaging\WriteableBitmap.cs:line 271
   at Program.Main() in Program.cs:line 15
```

### Regression?

I don't think so.

### Known Workarounds

None

### Impact

Unknown

### Configuration

.NET 8, Windows 11, x64. I don't think this is specific.

### Other information

None. 

Maybe uint should be used somewhere instead of int in the internal offset calculations?

Issues.Title: Replace boxing ArrayLists in UIAutomationClientSideProviders (ClickablePoint)
Issues.Body:
## Description

This should be the last boxing `ArrayList` that's still left in `UIAutomationClientSideProviders` when #9388 would be merged.

- Adds `System.Collections` reference to `UIAutomationClientSideProviders` to allow for generic collections in the first place.
- Removes two boxing `ArrayList` instances, both times for `CPRect` structure in `ClickablePoint` and `ProxySimple` class.
- Makes the static fields `readonly` and moves the other static field init into the `static constructor` for readability.
- Adjusts the `CPRect` bool methods as `readonly` since they do not modify struct state.
- Renames the "al*" params as "list*" to reflect reality this ain't an `ArrayList`.
- Adjusts internal comments from "Program" to "Progman".

## Customer Impact

Improved performance, decreased allocations.

## Regression

No.

## Testing

Local build.

## Risk

Low.
